Quality summary from #montanafreepress. BOZEMAN — The Gallatin County Democrats hosted a Senate candidate forum at Bozeman’s Emerson Center for the Arts & Culture Feb. 21. Candidate John Mues used the occasion to suggest that the nomination of any of his fellow primary candidates to the general election ballot would give incumbent Republican Steve Daines a “free pass” to re-election.  The hardball assessment stood out in the context of an event that was less a proper debate than an introduction to the candidates, and an opportunity for the Gallatin County Democratic Central Committee to solicit money to support the slate.  Mues was the only one of the five Democrats angling to challenge Daines who put forward an aggressive case for himself, specifically, as the candidate best positioned by experience and expertise to unseat the incumbent, whom several of the evening’s candidates referred to as an “existential threat.”  Helena Mayor Wilmot Collins made the same claim to electability, but without much effort to make a specific case. Bozeman-based State Department veteran and health-and-economic-development nonprofit founder Cora Neumann presented a strong case for her expertise in health care policy, and was laser-focused on the importance of “flipping the Senate.” Bozeman’s Michael Knoles proved himself the most systemically radical and emotionally excitable of the contenders, making a closing-statement claim that “we are a parasite on this earth and we are destroying it because we do not understand the consequences of our actions.” Bozeman fishing guide Josh Seckinger, who’d entered the race just two days earlier, rarely used the entirety of his allotted one minute for answers, and promised to depart in two days to visit all of Montana’s 56 counties and win the nomination “with gas and coffee and cheap motel rooms.” He made a solid case that he’s an excellent guy to share a boat with.  Mues’ effort to transcend the crowded field risked running afoul of the all-in-this-together vibe of an assembly that reserved its most approving responses for attacks on Daines and Republican U.S. House Rep.-turned-gubernatorial candidate Greg Gianforte. Half a dozen times, Mues, a navy veteran, former teacher, rancher, and energy-sector engineer who lives in Loma, stated some variant of the assertion that he was “the only candidate on the stage” with the right combination of small-town pedigree, agricultural know-how, military credentials, and business acumen to take down Daines. Neumann’s occasional side-eye in response to the claims was the only sign that any of the other four candidates might challenge him directly on that.  #mtpol

Dorothy Bradley Endorses John Mues for U.S. Senate Montana thought-leader and accomplished public servant, Dorothy Bradley, announced today that she is endorsing John Mues to be elected to replace U.S. Senator Steve Daines.      With her endorsement of John Mues to be elected to the U.S. Senate, Dorothy Bradley issued this statement:   “I recently met John Mues at a gathering with friends, and without knowing he was running for office, I left the conversation thinking, ‘Now there is a gracious young Montanan with a lot of leadership potential.’  I was elated to discover that he is out on a political trail, and the more I know, the more hopeful I feel. “John’s background in the military service, energy engineering, and education is made to order for a country whose present leadership seems bent on foreign policy by whim, climate change by denial, and education-to-the-minimum. “I am as exhausted by our rudeness to each other as with the shrillness and fruitlessness of our politics.  Wallace Stegner called the west the “native land of hope”.  I’m thinking John is one of the new, young leaders rising to the fore that just might bring it back.” Throughout her career, Bradley served eight terms in the Montana House of Representatives from 1971 to 1978 and from 1985 to 1992.  Bradley ran two statewide campaigns, seeking election to the U.S. Congress and to serve as the Democratic nominee for Governor of Montana, during which she became well-known for riding her horse across the Big Sky State. “The modern leaders of Montana, including Dorothy Bradley, inspire my candidacy and give me the confidence that my focus on working for the benefit of all Montanans – not wealthy corporations and PAC money lobbyists – is the right strategy for Montana and for my campaign,” said John Mues.  “I am truly honored to have the enthusiastic endorsement of Dorothy Bradley, one of Montana’s most significant thought-leaders and contributors in public policy and service to fellow Montanans.”    About John Mues John Mues is a candidate running a campaign to defeat U.S. Senator Steve Daines in the Fall 2020 election.  Mues is a 4th generation Montanan who was raised in a single-parent household in Helena, Deer Lodge, and Wolf Point, the son of a social worker mother and Vietnam Veteran father who worked as a union letter carrier. The beneficiary of quality public school teachers and coaches in Montana, John received a Congressional nomination to the U.S. Naval Academy, from which he graduated with academic honors while lettering in Division I sports.  John then trained in the U.S. Navy as a submarine warfare officer and nuclear engineer, as well as attaining Army Airborne Parachutist and Navy Diver qualifications. While overseas on active military duty, John applied to the Troops-to-Teachers program and worked towards a teaching certificate through Montana State University.  Two months after being honorably discharged from the U.S. Navy, he began two years of differentiated service to country as a high school math and English teacher on the Ft. Belknap Indian Reservation in north central Montana, helping build programs that encourage student success and recognition in one of the state’s highest needs schools. In 2008, as the Great Recession set in, John entered the private sector as a senior engineer in the energy sector, where he has worked for the past 11 years making America energy independent, pursuing renewable clean energy, and contributing to living wage jobs in Montana and throughout the country.  During this period, he also earned a Master in Business Administration (MBA) from the London Business School John and his wife Claudia, a non-profit leader, live near Loma in the north central part of Montana. They are expecting their first child, the 5th generation of John’s family to call Montana home, later in 2019. Our 56 County Mues for Montana Road Trip keeps trucking with great momentum and enthusiasm. We're going to beat Senator Daines, folks. Here's a weekly summary (28 July-04 Aug 2019): 16.  Today, Sunday, just catching up on email and admin, and thinking back on yet another amazing week in our campaign for U.S. Senate.  We already have the U.S. House of Representatives, but without the U.S. Senate in hand, as well, our options oscillate between bad and unconscionably bad.  As a nation, we need to address the critical challenges of our day and times, and stop wasting time.  That’s why this race is, arguably, one of our nation’s most important.  Montana should be leading the charge in Flipping the Senate.  I believe it is, once again.    15.  In BOZEMAN on Saturday, we attended the Sweet Pea Festival and had a blast talking with artisans, sellers and buyers of amazing Montana goods.  We must be doing something right as I was downright shocked when, as we parked and got out of our truck, a family passed by and said, “We know you!  We think you can beat Senator Daines!  Keep it up!”  Well, Elizabeth, you’re right about that, and thank you for being prescient!  That’s, in fact, our central reason for running:  Beat Daines.   14.  In THREE FORKS, stood alongside union workers at the Imerys Talc Plant, commemorating their sacrifice and success from last year’s lock-out.  I’m not always easily moved, but this one got to me.  It’s important to remember that, while executive pay, hedge fund manager pay, private equity fund manager pay, investment bankers’ pay, foreign investors’ pay, and the stock market have skyrocketed over the last several decades, the American worker, normalized for inflation, has not gotten a pay raise.  The locked-out workers at Imerys stood solid for over 100 days, and ultimately got a multi-year deal that recognized their key value.  It was a hard-earned win-win outcome by which the best interests of Imerys and Montana workers were championed – as it should be in America.  It was an honor to be a part of this remembrance – sincere thanks to Al Ekblad, Randy Tocci, and Andrew Linton and the workers of Imerys for allowing us to participate.   13.  In DEER LODGE, had the pleasure of securing two important endorsements from state-wide stakeholders (announcement forthcoming), and a generous donation from a former popular governor.  Many thanks! 12.  In ANACONDA, took the Pintler Scenic Bypass through Anaconda – one of the most beautiful drives in Montana with majestic Mount Hagin on the left, the Flint Creek Mountains on the right, and Georgetown Lake, Discovery Ski Basin, and Philipsburg up ahead.  We stopped at the Anaconda Job Corps, ten miles outside of town, met with administrators, instructors, and students, took a generous 2 hour tour (thanks Duffy!), and walked away with a better sense of the debacle that Senator Daines caused, then walked back.  I also left with the belief that had Senator Daines not been up for re-election, the Anaconda Job Corps, notwithstanding the efforts of other stakeholders, would probably be closed under a Trump Administration.  But this should not be the debate:  close or keep open the Anaconda Job Corps.  Montana’s and America’s success in the 21st century will in large part depend on Education, including a strong emphasis on trade and vocational training.  That’s what the Job Corps – from Heavy Equipment Operator to Heavy Equipment Maintenance, from Culinary to Carpentry, from Fire Suppression to Bricklaying, from Basic to Advanced Welding – epitomizes.  One talented student, Josh, aspires to work for SpaceX!  We should be looking at strengthening such programs, which help all Montanans and Americans, not routinely threatening them with closure, or expecting thanks from their administrators, instructors, and students if we reverse our fickle decision to defund.  And, one last thing…  the Job Corps represents great diversity.  There are kids from all walks of life, and geographies.  It even supports those with disabilities.  For instance, Rob, an autistic student, is not only learning carpentry, he’s adding a second skill set in bricklaying, and has legitimate work options ahead.  And, he looks up to his instructors, Davin and Mark, as father figures.  Job Corps helps in all sorts of ways.  The sense of family I observed was not only atypical, it was inspiring.   11.  At FAIRMONT HOT SPRINGS, met with state-wide teachers, administrators, and labor leaders participating in the Montana Professional Teacher Foundation Golf Scramble, and camped out and shook hands with folks at the 12th Hole – it had a good-sized pond in front of the tee box so folks seemed to hang around a split second longer at the 12th, assessing their drive.  Met folks from every corner of the state who are helping kids achieve their dreams, and, in turn, making our state, country, democracy, and economy strong.  Thanks to Eric Feaver, Erik Burke, Lauren Caldwell, and others for the opportunity to attend.   10.  Had a great meeting with key folks from AFL/CIO in HELENA at Steve’s Café.  Saw Governor Bullock at Steve’s and shook hands with arguably our next POTUS.  Then met good folks at MFPE and MDP, and had a great conversation and lunch with Larry Pettit, an incredible resource.  Also, thank you Monica Abbott and Sherry Leone for the terrific support and offer of prime acreage for a Mues for Montana sign!  Absolutely can’t do it without you!      9.  In LOMA last Sunday evening, organized with the help of one of the biggest employers in Chouteau County a Meet & Greet with local ranchers and farmers.  As much as I love the good Democrats in Montana’s major towns and cities, I’m always impressed with Democrats in the state’s most rural, red counties.  These people are as principled and resistant to peer pressure as anyone in the country!  The other thing I’m finding is that a lot of so-called Republicans and Independents are ready to come home to the Democratic Party.  They just need someone in whom they can believe and trust, whom understands and appreciates all parts of Montana, and whom can tell the difference between a top, middle, and bottom line.  That’s why we’re going to beat Senator Daines, and by a margin that sends a signal throughout Montana and the country that if you're hyper-partisan, beholden to special interests, and care more about your major donors than the multitudes of Montanans, you're going to get your clock cleaned.        1-8. My Op-Ed and "Open Letter to U.S. Senator Steve Daines", submitted 19 July, published in Missoulian yesterday.  (And stay turned for our next Op-Ed, recently submitted.) https://missoulian.com/opinion/columnists/daines-damages-montana-with-comments-votes/article_2dd1ce56-e205-5216-9998-1fe61518f22a.html An open letter to U.S. Sen. Steve Daines: Recently, Senator Daines, you called four young newly elected congresswomen of color — Alexandria Ocasio Cortez, Ayanna Pressley, Ilhan Omar, and Rashida Tlaib — on Twitter, “Anti-American” and “Anti-Semite.” Rather than retract your statement, you then went onto Fox News, doubled down, and even threw around the word “terrorist.” A U.S. senator’s words can have real meaning. Given your position, a number of people follow and trust you. In your epithets against these women — on Twitter and Fox News — you have effectively called for action, even violence, against them. After all, according to you, they are “Anti-American,” “Anti-Semite” and somehow connected with terrorism. Yet, these women have done absolutely nothing wrong. Their perspectives on public policy are different than yours because of the diversity and inequities of the communities that they represent. But they are each as American as you or me, and they love their country every bit as much as we do. I would know, as I served as an Annapolis-commissioned naval officer alongside brave Americans from a multitude of backgrounds, whose diversity improved our teams’ effectiveness. In contrast, you have put these young women in harm’s way. This is not an outlying example, senator.
